fields.headline: BBC Question Time: live blog
fields.bodyText: Ed Davey distils the limbo of coalition - not yet ready to tear into one another, still having to defend jointly made policies and decisions, unhappy to ally with the conservatives “going forward” (as the modern parlance has it)... it’s an unenviable position, and one that hopefully all parties will remember if there’s ever a coalition agreement in the offing in 2015. Goodnight. Tessa Jowell made a good fist of reminding us of her part in the Olympics, but otherwise was a damp squib. Russell Brand won the popularity contest, clearly; but also moved a number of self-evidently true things into a public domain that persists in refuting them (eg, people take drugs when they feel helpless, there’s no point just attacking the drug use; there isn’t enough housing for people to live in; rich people need to pay more tax). I would love to see more of him on the pop current affairs circuit. Bojo is being uncharacteristically cautious, which means he has either stepped up his leadership ambitions or decided to stop hiding them. Either that, or he genuinely doesn’t know what to do about Syria, has genuinely never met anyone who’s taken drugs, and genuinely doesn’t know how much an affordable home would be. In conclusion: Melanie Phillips is interesting... there’s clearly some pantomime element to the way she argues - witness that Brand liked her in the green room, she can clearly talk to people she disagrees with, without shouting at them. And yet her behaviour towards the audience was as unpleasant as I’ve ever seen a panellist be. Schoolmarmish one minute, hectoring the next... Part of me thinks this is deliberated, a move into the pinata phase of her career. For a longer time, you numptie! (That was to Ed Davey, who has somehow spinned, to himself, the line that £9k is less money than £3k.) This is exactly it - when you refuse to see housing as a matter of policy, you will inevitably end up with the conclusion “this is bad, but I don’t know.” It’s nothing like good enough. That’s why they’re all on drugs, Melanie! Over the next spending period, the government has £96billion earmarked for housing benefit and £4billion earmarked for building new homes. Then they turn round and say “this benefit bill is unsustainable” as if that’s somehow the fault of people who can’t afford their rent, that a government has no systematic housing policy. Rents in London have gone up by eight times as much as wages. There is a problem with somebody *whistles* flogging off housing stock and never building any more, and there is a problem with a lack of social housing, but there’s a problem with wages as well. Tax is, as Polly Toynbee memorably said, an “I’ll do it if you’ll do it” deal. Hassling comedians to pay it voluntarily betrays a misunderstanding of the purpose of taxation. Sorry about the cats and the pigeons, by the way. I thought MP was going to have a conniption. This QT hasn’t played to BoJo’s strengths at all. He’s extremely keen not to nail his colours to the mast on any of this, possibly with an eye to an unblemished diplomatic record for the future, but this makes it impossible for him to mobilise the thing that people like about him, viz, that he tells it like it is. I’m groping for a phrase... it’s something to do with cats, cats and pigeons. Someone on Twitter just accused me of having missed Melanie’s rant. I didn’t miss it. I just didn’t think it warranted closer inspection. Wow. I honestly did not see how Russell was going to get his great clap out of this issue, and he went straight for the great clap source. “We are providing non-lethal assistance to some of the rebels.” Ed Davey looks and sounds plausible, but it’s really hard to see what this would amount to. Agencies out there are unimpressed by the “non-lethal” response from governments. Do we think Phillips may have gone too far, calling the audience trivial and ignorant? More of the same; what’s in it for me? What do I get out of it all? “There are no good outcomes for us” This is an absolutely classic Phillips reading of everything. “What’s in it for me? What’s a good outcome for me? I don’t have a naval base in the Tartus! I don’t care about dead people!” Sorry, while the army types are rude to one another, check out the Mirror’s front page for tomorrow. BoJo’s answer is baffling, here - he’s looked into it very closely, he’s persuaded of Assad’s atrocities, yet he’s against arming anyone, he doesn’t have any other ideas... It’s like one giant shrug. It’s an interesting tactic, this; he does seem to be cultivating this impression that he has some other urgent thing to do. It must be deliberate. It’s not like Boisdales is going anywhere.* *In truth I have no idea where he eats. What I don’t understand is why politicians think the decriminalisation argument is so toxic, for voters. Anyone who’s at all interested in drug policy should watch this documentary - The House I Live In, by Eugene Jarecki. He makes a really strong case that drug laws in the US and, the way Melanie P would conceive them, in the UK, are basically a way to criminalise the poor (very strong racial context in the US). Trying to keep a clear head on the matter of Melanie Phillips, I do take agin her telling us that we’ve all lost a sense of integrity, a sense of honesty... I don’t see how this can be anything other than projection. Christine Lagarde is not a sensible person on the matter of women in the boardroom. I’m not wild about Tessa Jowell’s essentialist line that women are just better people than men. There’s evidence that women are more risk averse because there aren’t that many women on trading floors. If there were more women, there would doubtless be more women who were as reckless as men. It’s interesting to see how the crowd-pleasers, like Boris, respond to being on the same panel as Brand, who is basically going to make the audience clap him until their hands bleed. He will end up having to agree with him as much as he can, it seems to me. Most probably against his better judgment. I’m actually clapping at home, on my own. I just like Russell Brand's delivery. That’s not true about the toughest regime on bankers’ bonuses in the world, by the way. Switzerland is way tougher. Bankers there are often hired to do two simultaneous jobs to get round the fact that their salary and bonus caps are so strict. What’s interesting is that a lot of bankers would like to see a return to unlimited liability, old school Victorian partnerships where they were betting with their own money. I mean, I say that... it was a relatively small sample I interviewed. But it’s not a left-wing idea, that this socialised-losses, privatised-gains situation is a stupid one. The gamblers themselves claim not to like it. Evening everyone. Getting ready for Question Time; as always on a Thursday night at around this time, I have hopes, I have dreams. I hope the audience is full of lefties who clap in a partisan way; I like the rattled look the panels gets, as if they’ve skirted a bit too close to the rabble. I hope I don’t get so drunk that I’m immobilised by the end and have to watch This Week; but most of all, I hope for a conversation in which people appear to be saying what they actually mean, and have actually thought about, rather than rehearsing over-simplified triple-line non-explanations they got from central office or headquarters or whatever grandiose word they have for a room full of 27-year-olds who think the general public is only interested in low taxes. That’s what I dream of. Russell Brand will obviously be good in this sense, obeying only the head office of his heart, or the heart office of his head, or whatever; Boris Johnson, whose greatest fan I amn’t, is good on this score as well. Onwards! Let dreams take wing!
